COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,    ,            , 2023) | COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,    ,            , 2023)
Bachelor of Software Engineering | Bachelor of Software Engineering

* Title: Java Programming	Code: CNTT1153
* Credits: 3 (45)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 25 hrs.
+ Exercises in class: 10 hrs.
+ Presentation and Discussion: 10 hrs.
+ Self-study: 60 hrs.
* Parallel course(s):
* Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1128, CNTT1131
* Department conducting the course:
+ Faculty: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334)
+ Lecturers:
1. PhD. Phạm Xuân Lâm	Tel: 0937638683	Email: lampx@neu.edu.vn
2. MSc. Phạm Thảo	Tel: 0966986689	Email: thaop@neu.edu.vn
* The course:

Foundation □ | Foundation □ | Fundamental (x) | Fundamental (x)
Compulsory □ | Elective □ | Compulsory □ | Elective (x)
* Course language: 	In English
* Meeting hour: 8AM – 11AM on Wednesdays, Room 13.10, Building A1, National Economics University

This course provides foundational knowledge in Java programming, such as OOP, input/output processing, multithreading, and using libraries to build user interfaces (UI). The content of the course includes Basics of Java programming; Object-oriented programming; Exception handling; Input/output processing; Collection frameworks; Generic programming; Java 8+ features. The course also aims to develop critical thinking skills, the ability to self-learn knowledge, and technologies related to Java by working independently as well as in groups. Students will be divided into groups to delve deeper into various technologies, allowing them to present and discuss individual or group solutions to address issues.

* Textbooks/Lecture Notes:
[1] Pham Xuan Lam (2024), Java Programming, National Economics University
* Additional references:
[2] Introduction to Programming Using Java – 8th David J. Eck
[3] Thinking in Java 4th Edition (2000) – Bruce Eckel (Practice Hall)

Table 4. Course goals
Goals | Goals Description | Proficiency scale
G1 | The course provides fundamental knowledge of programming in Java, helping students understand the principles of Java programming and apply knowledge of algorithms to software development. Students will be able to analyze, design, program, and test application using the Java programming language. | 3-4
G2 | The course enhances critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, and practical skills in the profession to address IT-related tasks using Java. | 3U
G3 | The course contributes to the development of independent work and teamwork skills, fostering a proper understanding of responsibility in task execution and professional ethics. | 3

Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)
Goals | CLOs | CLOs Description | Teaching level (I, T, U)
G1 | CLO1.1 | Understanding how software work on computers, the computer programming languages used to create software, such as the Java; Describing Java technology, classifying types of Java applications; Basic programming with Java. | I
G1 | CLO1.2 | Understanding the basic programming techniques, such as control flow; function; object-oriented; input/output, multithread, applying in the development of applications. | T
G1 | CLO1.3 | Applying testing techniques, quality assessment, software performance evaluation, as well as GUI to build applications. | U
G2 | CLO2.1 | Having the skills to search, gather, synthesize, analyze, and present information to solve problems related to Java programming. | U
G2 | CLO2.2 | Having the ability to coordinate and collaborate to solve group assignments, ensuring the team completes tasks according to schedule. | U
G2 | CLO2.3 | Having the skills to use tools to optimize code and reduce programming time. | U
G3 | CLO3.1 | Having the ability to self-study and research relevant Java to complete assigned tasks. | U
G3 | CLO3.2 | Having a sense of organization and discipline in the classroom, adhering to class rules, demonstrating a cooperative spirit, and taking personal responsibility for assigned activities. | U
G3 | CLO3.3 | Understanding the responsibilities in task execution, maintaining professional ethics in tasks related to Java programming. | U

- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
8.3. Requirements for in-class behavior
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behavior that affects the teaching and learning process is prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
